Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces that govern the universe and is the force of attraction between objects with mass or energy. It is a relatively weak force individually but becomes significant when dealing with larger objects. The force of gravity between two objects depends on their masses and the distance between them, decreasing as the square of the distance increases. 

On Earth, gravity gives weight to physical objects and influences their fall towards the ground. It is also responsible for the orbits of celestial bodies, including the Earth around the sun. Gravity is a crucial element in understanding the cosmos and has been central to our understanding of the universe's structure, from the smallest particles to the largest galaxies.

Gravity also causes the bending of spacetime, which leads to phenomena such as the orbits of planets and the tidal bulges in oceans.

Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces that govern physical interactions, the others being electromagnetism and the strong and weak nuclear forces. It is a force that exists between all objects, pulling them together. It is described by the general theory of relativity that was proposed by Albert Einstein. The theory suggests that gravity is not a force that acts between masses, but instead is a result of the curvature of spacetime, caused by mass and energy. This curvature leads objects to move along geodesic lines, which appear as the straightest possible paths, giving the appearance of a mutual attraction between masses. The strength of gravity is determined by an object's mass, with larger objects exerting a greater gravitational pull.
